Just as fair weather, purified into the purest brilliancy, does not admit of a still greater degree of clearness3 so, when a man takes care of his body and of his soul, weaving the texture of his good from both, his con- ditionis perfect, and he 1135 found the consummation of his prayers, if there is no connnotion in his soul or pain in his body. whatever delights fall to his lot over and above these two things do not increase his Supreme Good; they merely season it, so to speak, and add spice to it. For the absolute good of man's nature is satisfied with peace in the body and peace in the soul.
